citation.article-title: A succinoglycan-decompising bacterium. Cytophaga arvensicola sp. nov.
citation.source: The Journal of General and Applied Microbiology

p.s: Description of Cytophaga arvensicola sp. nov.
Cytophaga arvensicola (ar. yen. si' co. la. L. adj. arvensis arable; L, n. -cola dweller; M. L, fem. n. arvensicola arable land dweller or inhabitant)
The general characteristics of this species are: Cells rod-shaped, ranging from 0.3 to 0.4 μm by 0.6 to 4.0 μm.
Well spreading segregants on YP agar may occur during preservation.
Hydrogen sulfide not detected in the butt of the TSI agar.
Acid produced oxidatively from various sugars but not anaerobically.
Utilize D-xylose, L-arabinose, D-glucose, D-fructose, cellobiose, maltose, sucrose, raffinose, and succinoglycan.
Esculin is hydrolyzed, and Tween 40, 60, and 80 are not hydrolyzed.
Range of DNA base composition 42.8 to 46.0%.
The characteristics of the type strain, M64 (=IAM 12650), listed in Tables 3-9, are as follows:
Rods 0.3 μm by 0.8 to 2.0 μm on YP agar, occur singly.
No variation in cell morphology observed in old cultures.
Spreading growth not observed on any agar media.
YP agar colonies circular, smooth, convex, entire, translucent, and yellow orange.
Water-soluble pigment negative on YP agar and King A and B media.
Nitrate reduction positive in nitrate broth and nitrate-succinate broth.
Acid production (OF medium) : Acid but no gas produced from D-ribose, D-xylose, D-arabinose, L-arabinose, D-glucose, cellobiose, lactose, maltose, and trehalose.
Acid and gas not produced from D-fructose, sucrose, raffinose, salicin, glycerol, and ethanol.

Utilization of carbohydrates : Grows at the expense of D-ribose, D-xylose, L-arabinose, D-glucose, D-fructose, cellobiose, maltose, sucrose, raffinose, succinoglycan, pectin, and carboxymethylcellulose.
Does not grow at the expense of starch, inulin, polypectate, cellulose, heparin, alginate, chitin, and agar.
NaCl-broth: Grows at 1 % but does not grow at 5 %.
Growth temperature : Grows at 5° and 37° but not at 42°.
Cellular fatty acids major components i-C15:0, Δ11 C15:0, 2-OH i-C16:1, and 3-OH i-C17:0.
Source: Soil of Osaka Prefecture, Japan (6).

The other seven strains of C. arvensicola have been deposited in Institute of Applied Microbiology (IAM) : Strain A4L (IAM 12646), strain A4S (IAM 12647), strain A21L (IAM 12648), strain A21S (IAM 12649), strain G8 (IAM 12651), strain 469 (IAM 12653), and strain 474 (IAM 12654).
